Goucho Day. Due to a strike that shut down the highway we took well over an extra hour to get to the ranch (no fault of driver or organizers). However, the town walk was somewhat hurried and we were unable to browse or shop for silver or leather goods.The horse show was interesting and there was lots of food but it wasn't outstanding by any means. Our guide Laura and driver Caesar were both professional and interesting.

What a fabulous day out it was..... We ummmed and ahhhhed about doing this tour mainly because it was going to be at the end of long, wonderful but expensive holiday however I am so so pleased we did as it was one of the highlights of the trip. We had door to door transfers by the marvellous Jose Maria, who rocked. He was extremely knowledgeable about Buenos Aires and just generally set the tone for a brilliant day.The tour of San Antonio De Acreo was interesting and provided a perfect balm to BA and the Estancia ahhhh the Estancia. It was beautiful, the horse ride ( optional but highly recommended even for those of us who are not naturally horsey) the food, Oscar the gaucho all were wonderful and I think a must if you are visiting Argentina. Something seriously not to be missed.

A great day away from the city. We wanted to get out of Buenos Aires and see the countryside. We weren't sure what to expect but this day greatly exceeded our expectations. We were picked up at our hotel by Miguel who was our driver for the day - a very nice and professional driver in a very comfortable car. He drove us to San Antonio where we met Laura, our guide. She grew up in the area and lived in San Antonio so was very knowledgeable. Having been an English teacher, her English was flawless! After an interesting walking tour of San Antonio we visited the estancia where we rode horses (in a group) out on the pampas and had a great BBQ lunch and Malbec (labelled for the estancia). First class!!When in Buenos Aires, we highly recommend this excursion so that you see and experience more than just the city!

Highly recommended - a really great day. We chose this tour because we liked the idea of being in a small group. Turned out it was just the two of us this day. Caesar picked us up from our hotel up and drove us to San Antonio (we thought he was a particularly careful driver) where we were met by Juan Manuel who took us on a brief but very informative tour of the town visiting the church, the chocolate shop, the general store and the silversmith. At the Estancia, which is a truly beautiful property, we were welcomed with a drink served on the shaded verandah then toured the estate by horse and buggy. We could have had a swim in a beautifully located outdoor pool, or a horse ride instead. Later Juan Manuel joined us for a delicious 3 course lunch, wine, generous servings of barbecued meats, salad vegetables grown on the property, a very tasty icecream dessert, and coffee. All this accompanied by one of the older gauchos playing guitar and singing local songs. With other guests we watched an amazing display of "horse whispering" then toured the guest facilities before starting on our one and half hour return trip to Buenos Aires. Juan Manuel was very informative, enthusiastic and fun to be with - and even arranged the chocolates we'd bought be kept cool in the house refrigerator!!!!

Magical day In San Antonio de Areco Town and Estancia. From the on time pickup from Jose Maria through meeting Juan Manual in San Antonio de Areco town for a tour of this lovely town to our day at the Estancia, this was a magical day. The town square was fun to visit, the church of San Antonio de Padua and its wonderful history, the silversmiths where they displayed gorgeous silver work, the Chocolate Factory with the wonderful alfajores- you must try these. They are fantastic. Upon arrival at the Estancia, we were treated to the best empanadas we had in Argentina along with some great Malbec. After horseback riding for some and a carriage ride for others, we enjoyed a fabulous lunch. Many salads made with ingredients from their garden were served. Next came grilled sausages, grilled chicken(the best I've ever tasted). grilled beef and ribs. This was followed by chocolate dipped ice cream. Great Malbec and Chardonnay as well as soft drinks and water were served as well. During lunch we were treated to some wonderful music and song presented by one of the gauchos. After lunch, another of the gauchos demonstrated how their horses are trained. After this wonderful day, we returned to Buenos Aires with lots of great memories. Next time in Argentina, we will look to spend an overnight there. They have several guest rooms. This location is beautiful. It was wonderful to hear the birds chirping and enjoy the peacefulness of the country after the hustle and bustle of BA.

Fantastic. Picked up promptly at hotel in Palermo Soho by Jose Maria. He was friendly and informative about B.A. and the drive to San Antonio. In the town we were met by Juan Manuel, who was a fascinating individual. Well traveled and curious, he was easy to talk to and enthusiastic, not only about the subject matter, but about the world. A perfect person to introduce us to the history of the Gaucho and life on the Pampas.Tour of the town was brief and informative. Stopped at a local silversmith, which I thought would be a "sales stop" you see on other tours, but instead was simply an introduction to the relationship of silver to the Gaucho, and the iconography of the group. There was a stop at a local chocolate shop as well for what were the best Alfajors I had in Buenos Aires. Only down side was since it was a hot day, there would have been no way to hold onto the chocolates without them melting while at the Estancia. The Estancia was a peaceful setting. It was a small group (went on a Monday) of maybe 20 people. The horse ride was idyllic and tranquil, and you get a great sense of ranch and life on the pampas. Lunch was a typical feast from the parrilla, executed perfectly. Treated to traditional songs by a noted Gaucho, and a horse taming display that underlined a humane relationship between humans and horse. What a peaceful, relaxing respite from Buenos Aires. I would not only go again, but I would stay for a few nights at the Estancia's B&B.

A Relaxing, wonderful getaway with some very pleasant people : ). This tour was the highlight of our vacation. Our driver, Jose Maria,was so attentive, knowledgeable, genuine and a true professional. Juan Manuel aka "The Most Interesting Man in the World" was equally as knowledgeable, pleasant and a joy to be with. He was funny too!....he had us in stitches the whole time. The grounds of the Estancia are very pristine. Their horses and dogs are very well cared for. Their staff were all very hospitable. We especially enjoyed the Gaucho presentation during lunch. This tour is a must! A real Gem!
Best tour ever!. Jose and Juan Manuel are the best: classy, fun, energetic, and extremely intelligent/cultured. Thank you!

What a wonderful day. A truly exceptional experience. We loved it. The guides (Jose Maria and Manuel) were great. The town is enchanting Kevin Farrell is a true reminder of God's own country. The estancia with its much loved rescue dogs and hospitable staff provided outstanding food. Despite all this the highlight was the gaucho display - with both guitar and horse. As Manuel would say“From this day to the ending of the world,But we in it shall be remembered-We few, we happy few, we band of brothers;For he to-day that sheds his blood with meShall be my brother; be he ne’er so vile,This day shall gentle his condition;And gentlemen in England now-a-bedShall think themselves accurs’d they were not here,And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaksThat fought with us upon Saint Crispin’s day.”

Great way to see the Pampas and Gauchos of Argentina. Lara was our guide and Jose our driver. Both were wonderful and very pleasant to spend the day with. I made my reservation about 3 months in advance and by email - very quick and easy response. Jose was right on time outside my hotel on Florida Ave, and unfortunately I was waiting at the wrong corner (Florida Ave a pedestrian street). Luckily I realized this and he was still there. I suggest emailing them a day or so in advance just to let them know you are still planning to be there in case this happens to you. Jose recommended the alfajores at the chocolate shop and they were very good. They will sell you some in a wooden crate so they don't break in your suitcase too. The town was interesting to see and didn't feel like a tourist trap. Gives you good opportunity to see the craftsmen. Very charming old town. The Estancia (Ombra?) is VERY nice and sooo authentic feeling and looking (because it is). Food is SO good - mm that asada meat. Wine, empanadas and more. The gaucho singer was really cool. Loved the gaucho horse whispering performance. Horse right very tranquil and just the right amount of time - about 45 min to an hour. You get to see some cool things on the road to and from along the way also, like the football stadium and some suburb neighborhoods, how people live and commute etc.Note - They ask that you pay in USD, Euros, and you pay at end so make sure you don't forget this as the charge in pesos is much higher, which is what you'd have to do if you forget. ATMs are terrible and you cant take money out.

Great time... Maria is the best - Gracias. We had a little rain, but they still made our experience very enjoyable. We took a day trip for Argentina and it was just the getaway we were looking for. The estancia is beautiful.

Camino Pampa was Fantastic. This was a great experience with great people - one of the highlights of a 2.5 week trip to Argentina. My wife and I were picked up on November 8th promptly at 8:20 am from our Buenos Aires hotel in Recoleta by the wonderful Jose Maria. He drove us to the town of San Antonio de Areco, about 1.5 hours northwest of BsAs, and filled the entire time with history and answering our many questions. His English is excellent. We had him and the van all to ourselves because we were the only people visiting the town, while everyone else at the ranch that day went directly to the ranch. The owner of the tour company, Guillermo, was our guide in town when we arrived and we also had him to ourselves for the same reason. The colonial town was pleasant and I’m glad we added that to the experience. Among other things, Guillermo showed us around the main square, the beautiful church, a gaucho bar, and a silver and leather workshop. There was absolutely no pressure to buy anything, which is always appreciated. Guillermo is from the area and his enthusiasm showed. His English is also excellent, and he is both very professional and friendly at the same time. After more than an hour in town, Jose Maria drove us a short distance out of town to the El Ombu ranch. After an informal reception of empanadas (these were some of the best we had on our vacation) and various beverages (beer, Malbec, water, etc.), we rode horseback with a few gauchos. Lunch consisted of salad, rice, slaw, sausage, and the tastiest grilled chicken and beef. The lunch was followed by guitar playing, traditional dancing, and games on horseback all performed by the gauchos. It was late afternoon by the time Jose Maria drove us back to BsAs and the conversations continued. We really enjoyed our time in the van with him and were truly sad to part company once back at our hotel. You will not be disappointed with this day trip. Everything was excellent.

Great day trip outside of Buenos Aires. Our trip to San Antonio de Areco and the Estancia was awesome. The service on the trip was first class and our guide, Juan Manuel was the perfect person for this kind of trip. He was very knowledgable about the gaucho history and was also just a really fun person to spend the day with. I would highly recommend this activity as a nice day trip from Buenos Aires to get to see the countryside and get to know a Little more about the gaucho culture.
A nice day in the country.. Our hostess Maria made this an overall 4.5 out of 5 experience. We truly enjoyed her insight and company.

Amazing!. We absolutely loved our experience with Camino Pampa! We were traveling around Argentina quickly and cheaply, so this was a bit of a splurge. We debated spending the money, but were very glad we did! We were picked up in front of our hotel in a minibus/van with only one other couple aboard, who we enjoyed getting to know during the day's trip. It was about an hour/hour and a half drive outside of Buenos Aires, but very comfortable and enjoyable. We first stopped in the city of San Antonio de Areco and saw the local church, a silversmith's museum, and an artisan chocoloate shop. The history and information that Juan Manuel gave us was great! He was knowledgeable, knew everyone, and was funny! He was a great guide! After the the tour of the town we drove to the estancia. Arriving there had me awe; It was gorgeous! We got settled in and were offered empanadas and drinks (water, juice, wine, etc.). I'm vegetarian, and forgot to email them until late the night before, but when we mentioned it to Juan Manuel, he made sure to find me a veggie friendly snack and made sure that something special was prepared for our meal later. After our snack we had the option to browse the grounds, go on a carriage ride, or ride horses. We wanted to ride horses and had the most amazing time! I'm not a rider but have gone on tourist riding experiences before and felt a little uneasy. However, this time was amazing. The saddle was different than ones I've been on before and they made you feel comfortable and secure on the horse. I didn't want to ever stop! When the ride was over, we had about 15min or so before lunch was served so they offered to take me, my friend, & our new friend from the minibus ride back out. After the ride we had lunch outdoors on the lawn with large round tables and nice table settings. We had endless wine, and to my husband's and friends' delight, what seemed like endless offerings of Argentinian meats. Lunch was amazing and our guide, Juan Manuel, ate with us. We felt like friends by the end of the meal! Afterwards, we heard live gaucho music and saw a gaucho perform a ceremony with his horse. It was one of the best life experiences I've had! While this is a tour package, it doesn't feel touristy. The tour of the town was just us six and very personal and the owner of the estancia ate lunch with us so it felt like she was just having you over to her place. If you don't go on this tour, you're missing out!

Alondra's Happy Day. Of course I will write a review of our wonderful day! Everything, from pick up to drop off, was better than I had hoped. Throughout the day I had the strongest and strangest feeling of being at home in this place so far from home. The beauty, graciousness and humility of the people and the place filled my heart. In fact, after I'd been home from the South America trip for a couple of days and put on the CD of Oscar's music, I suddenly burst into tears, so strong was the memory of that happy day. Camino Pampa provides a great service.

Outstanding!. I had an excellent experience working with Guillermo and his team. All aspects, from the morning pick up to the afternoon drop off, were on-time, enjoyable, and exceeded expectations. Everyone we met was very accommodating and hospitable to us. Our tour guide, Manuel, took us on a private tour of the town of San Antonio and even brought us to a place to get homemade alfajores. So good. Also - I had the best empanadas I've ever tasted at the estancia. The trip is worth it for the empanadas alone! I would highly recommend this service and experience. Of all we did in Argentina, this ranked among my favorites.

A great day tour from BA. We booked the semi-private tour from BA which involved being picked up in a car from our hotel in BA and driven to San Antonio De Areco. There we met Juan Manuel who took us on a short walking tour of the town during which we visited 3 silversmiths. The work that they produced was of the highest quality (it is used for gifts for overseas heads of state) and was absolutely beautiful. There was no suggestion that we were expected to buy anything - it was more like visiting art galleries. We then got back in our car and drove the short distance to the Estancia. Once there, we had a quick drink before doing the horse riding (which was a short but enjoyable trail ride). There was also the options of swimming or a carriage ride. We then had a bbq lunch which was excellent followed by a performance on guitar by a Gaucho and a horse whispering demonstration. We then were returned by car to BA. This was a great day out which enabled us to see a bit more of Argentina. Juan Manuel was an excellent guide - he is very interesting and tells you a lot but not too much. The Estancia is a beautiful property and everything there was very well organised and run. I really recommend this tour.

Great day out!. Firstly we would like to thank they guys at Camino Pampa for being so flexible when we had to change the date of our tour and then the location of the pick up - everything was not a problem. On the day, we were collected on time at our hotel, we collected some other travellers and then off on the drive to the Estancia. During the trip our driver described local scenes and landmarks and being quite knowledgeable and speaking English, was able to answer some questions we had accumulated during the previous weeks in Argentina. On arrival at San Antonio de Areco - which is a quaint "caught in time" town, we were met by our guide, Juan, who was popular with the locals and took us on a walking tour describing the town, its history and the Gaucho culture. The tour of the pretty Church which was included, was very interesting with a couple of local jokes thrown in. The Alfajores at the chocolate shop are to die for, and the visit to the silver-smith was interesting. We were then off to the Estancia which is a beautiful old building. We were graciously greeted by one of the owners and offered a drink and some empanadas (the empanadas were excellent... the Malbec was nice too...). During this stop we were sized up for our horses and then we were off on a short ride around the property. We could have had a cart ride but everyone opted for horse-back. Not as picturesque as some rides we have done, but the horses were responsive and the riding easy. After this we enjoyed a delicious asado (bbq) under the shade of an old (planted 1806), huge, ombu tree - all you can eat and drink - accompanied by the property's dogs (they like to rescue dogs - they are VERY lucky dogs!). After this we were treated to a show of co-operation between a gaucho and his beautiful horse. Fantastic and beautifully controlled. You can see that they love their animals. This was a really enjoyable day without feeling like you were being bundled along to a tourist trap. This tour is a great way to slip out of Buenos Aires for a day.

San Antonio De Areco and Estancia Tour with Camino Pampa. Great daytrip out of BA. Quaint and interesting town of San Antonio De Areco, also visited estancia for horseback riding, asado and gaucho show. Laura was an excellent guide, very knowledgable and friendly. Definitely recommend the tour.
Amazing!. This was definitely one of the best experiences that I have ever had traveling. Our guide, Juan Manuel, was amazing and the farm was gorgeous. I'll definitely be back to visit!

Wonderful experience. Everything was very well organized. Guides are competent and give a lot of interesting information about the Gaucho culture, histrory etc. The estancia is an extremely nice place, we had a wonderful horse ride with gauchos followed by a good lunch. I recommend this tour to everyone.

Wonderful day in the countryside. We were a group of eight, mostly senior citizens arriving by cruise ship. The whole day was a delight and went exactly as we were told it would. We were met at the cruise terminal by Jose Maria, a gentleman who spoke beautiful English, was extremely knowledgeable about the area, and most importantly was patient and considerate of the senior citizens in our group. We spent much of the day with him as he drove us to the town of SA de Areco, to the estancia, and back to the cruise terminal. Once in the town we were greeted by Laura, another excellent tour guide. She had great stories and great information about the town, the history, and Argentinian life in general. We enjoyed her company very much and she also joined us at the estancia. SA de Areco is a charming town and we spent an enjoyable couple of hours there. Some members of our group were able to purchase quality leather and silver goods. The visit to the estancia was so relaxing! if you have seen the photos, you will know how beautiful it is there. The food and wine was not only plentiful, it was delicious! You will get to listen to some authentic guitar and gaucho songs from a very nice elderly gentleman and see an impressive performance of the horse whisperer. The whole day we encountered friendly, helpful, and gracious people, including the owner of the tour company, Guillermo. I would HIGHLY recommend this tour. Everyone in our group agreed that this was the best tour of the entire two weeks of their cruise. You will love this relaxing day in the countryside!

Wonderful experience. We had an excellent day out. We tend to avoid organised trips but the reviews for this were so good that we thought we would give it a try and are we glad we. The organisation was excellent. The tour of San Antonio d'Areco was interesting and informative although slightly truncated by recent flooding. The visit to the ranch was well organised but very relaxed and informal. We particularly enjoyed the horse related activities. Few of the group were experienced riders but this didn't stop us from having fun and feeling totally at ease on these wonderful horses. The barbecue and accompanying Malbec were also excellent set in the gardens of the estancia. We would like to send thanks to all involved.
The Gaucho visit was interesting. Me William is a good tour guide. He can speak fluent English and is really patient to introduce the Gaucho history and San Antonio city history.

Excellent getaway!. Good day in the countryside. The hosts are very friendly, amicable and willing to ensure the experience was second to none. I recommend this trip to anyone looking to explore what is outside of Bs As.

Wonder day trip from BA. The guide we had (Manuel) was very informative about the town of San Antonio. (The stop at the chocolate stop can't be missed). The Estancia trip was well organized and seeing the demo by the gaucho with his horse was very impressive. Food was excellent.

Fabulous day in the pampa. We had the best time ever at the estancia and such a laugh thanks to Juan our awesome driver, Manuel our extraordinary guide (great jokes!), Gloria the funniest chica in town;)!, Oscar for the amazing horse ride and all the crowd there... Family run ranch, beautiful surroundings, genuine people, great food, great atmosphere. Thanks to you all for this memorable stay.

Loved it!. Manuel is great! Very knowledgable of Bs As as well as well traveled around the world. He made our experience one to never forget! We explored and learned a lot in the silversmith building in town. We also enjoyed the alfajores at the local chocolate store.The empanadas at the estancia were phenomenal as was lunch. My husband wanted the horseback ride to be a bit longer but they were very accommodating and offered him another ride. We felt safe with our driver and he did wonderfully pointing out sights downtown after he picked us up. Def worth paying but more for the private tour. Make sure if you are to pay in USdollars then acquire them before you get to Argentina. We couldn't find US dollars anywhere around.

Excellent day trip outside of BA. After being in the busy city it was nice to see some of the countryside (reminds us of the midwest in the US) and see how life is in the smaller towns. Areco de San Antonio was a charming town. Reminded us how small town squares use to be. My only regret was not buying more chocolate at the chocolate shop they took us to. Don't make that same mistake. We really enjoyed the Estancia. Very beautiful, peaceful and just a nice, relaxing place to be. The food was plentiful and good. Overall just a wonderful experience that was not overly cheesy touristy either.

If you don't take this tour while in BA you've missed out!!!!!. I wanted my wife to have the experience of a lifetime when we were in BA, and really wanted us both to see the countryside as well as the hustle and bustle. I really don't even know how to properly describe the day we had thanks to Miguel and Manuel, as well as Diego and all of the wonderful folks at the Estancia...From Miguel's tour of the countryside on our way out, explaining what we were seeing as we drove the Pan American highway through the suburbs and into the rural areas, to Manuel's UNBELIEVABLE hospitality and knowledge of the town, area and Argentina in general, to the beauty of the farm and town, the kindness of the people, the amazing food and wine and the animals....By the way, for you Northern hemisphere folks reading this, you would not believe how cool it is to pull up to a GORGEOUS estancia like Ombu and see hundreds of wild parrots flying around...Crazy. This trip is not to be missed at twice the price. I am most definitely not a "tour" kind of guy--they always leave me feeling like I've either been shined on by someone who was paid to be my friend or part of a cattle call--but have on occasion tried some while in Europe that were nice. This simply wasn't a tour; it was like we were hanging out with this really cool friend of ours and all his friends at their home in the country, drinking wine, hearing wonderful music, riding horses, and even participating in a birthday celebration!

A great way to spend a day outside BA. Most other reviewers have explained the format of this trip - our day was consistent in terms of structure. the day is very well organised - from being met by our driver Cesar and host for the day Jean-Remi Weiss to meeting our guide Laura in San Antonio and then going on to the Estancia. Everything worked smoothly, the atmosphere was excellent. Jean-Remi was fun to be with, well informed about BA and Argentina in general and great company. Laura knows everything there is to know about San Antonio, estancia life, the history of the region and the gaucho and just about everything else Argentinian, including the local drink ( a rather strong and bitter tea called Mate, a really acquired taste)!All in all, a highly recommended way to spend a lovely relaxing day with a meat overload during the lunch BBQ and an amazing horse-whispering moment from one of the Estancia's gauchos.

K & A. We really enjoyed our day with Manuel in the Pampas, it was really a relaxing and wonderful experience - we still think about it a lot. Manuel felt like a good friend rather than a tour guide, and we talked about all sorts of things that day - from Malaysia to PETA and all! - while enjoying an interesting day in the outdoors. We also appreciated Guillermo coming to pick us up and his explanations about Argentina on the way there - everyone was just really friendly and welcoming. Thanks so much Camino Pampa, we will definitely recommend you guys to our friends who are thinking of visiting Argentina!

A day out to remember!. We decided to escape the city and head out to the Pampas.. so glad we did! Our guide Manuel was awesome, and helped us feel like one of the locals instead of an awkward tourist. His knowledge of the area and the history of the people was great not to mention his wicked sense of humour. The Estancia was beautiful, and it was an absolute pleasure to sit under the tree and enjoy the platters of mouthwatering BBQ'd meat. I highly recommend this tour, and I will be back in a heartbeat!

A MUST Do When in BA. Question:What do you need to have a great day tour? Answer: A fabulously informative, passionate, interesting guide and a beautiful location with a glimpse into another culture. This tour has both! Manuel is quite probably the best guide I have ever had the pleasure of spending a day with. Cesar, our driver, made our journey another opportunity to learn more about BA as he pointed out places of interest. The Estancia Umbu is not to be missed. If you don't feel like joining the gauchos for a horseback ride, settle in to a chair on the lawn and enjoy the fresh air and quiet.

A great day in the Pampas !. This was the most interesting tour when staying BA. The driver drove our small group of 5 to the small town of San Antonio de Areco. This is where we met our tour guide, Manuel. He was very knowledgeable and passionate about the gaucho culture and Argentina in general. We went to the interesting Gaucho museum and the tasty artisanal chocolate shop . We then went to the Estancia, authentically Argentinian and with real working gauchos, where we rode really well trained horses for around 1/2 hr. Then, in the estancia dining room, we had a very good Asado lunch, which included also different kind of salads and Malbec wine. After lunch we were entertained with guitar music performed by the elder gaucho. We then went outside and saw a performance by one the main gaucho and his horse that really highlighted the special bond they forge. After that we drop off our guide and were drove back to the city .I strongly recommend this adventure if you visit Buenos Aires and well worth the fee. Everyone was great from the driver on!

Best Day Out. This was so much fun, we had the best outing ever. The driver collected us from our apartment on time and drove us to the small town of San Antonio. This is where we met our tour guide, Manuel. He was such an amazing person, full of life, laughs and knowledge. Walked around the town and the quaint shops, must visit the chocolatier! Manuel then took us to the Estancia which was out of this world, authentically Argentinian with a fantastic Asado lunch and Malbec. I also rode a horse for the first time ever, gaucho Javier helped me along then it was my turn to get on with it. A must if you visit Buenos Aires and well worth the fee. Manuel made our day, thanks so much to all involved.

Wonderful experience with Manuel on Camino Pampa tour of San Antonio de Areco and Estancia Ombu. Well done!. The one-day tour exceeded expectations. Manuel and our driver, Cesar, are cordial and knowledgeable. The visits in town and all aspects of the visit to Estancia Umbu were superlative.

like visiting with good friends. We pleased above expectations by our tour guide. Picked us up at hotel, shared a bit of history on way to San Antonio, showed us all around the lovely little town, , introduced us to some interesting local friends of his & bought us cafe which we drank outdoors on the town square. Then Juan Miguel drove us to the Estancia Ombu, a working ranch nearby. We were promptly served empanadas & a drink on the relaxing porch. I strongly suggest not eating more than 1 as it will spoil the appetite for the nice BBQ (parillada) meal served later on. It was tasty, although chewy, meats, sausage & chicken with some potatoes & salad. We rode horses with our own Gaucho guide for just 2 of us. Riding on the Pampas had been on my bucket list.& I was not disappointed. Our interesting & eclectic guide made the day and I'm sure I didn't tip him enough. it was a lovely experience.

A perfect day!. We had a marvellous tour at San Antonio de Areco town and Umbu de Areco hacienda. Guillermo was an excellent guide, giving us all the information we need to merge into the gaucho folklore. We strongly recommend Camino Pampa agency and specially this tour.

Great Day Trip. My husband and I were looking for a day trip and decided on this one - what a great decision! The driver was punctual and zipped us right up to San Antonio de Areca where the tour guide - Juan Manuel - was waiting to meet us. Juan Manuel is a riot - humorous, and non-stop - he's very knowledgeable about the town, and the gaucho history and speaks perfect English.We strolled around the town visiting various stores and artisans and were not rushed at all. We had a great time at the Estancia - we rode horses (!) and had a meet fueled lunch which endless with some beautiful music.I definitely recommend this tour for anyone looking to get out of the city for the day and learn about a different part of Argentina's history..

Juan Manuel rocks!. Juan Manuel Hernandez is a fantastic guide, who is eager to share his wealth of knowledge about the Argentine pampas and the history of the gaucho culture with visitors. He is funny, kind, and seems to know everyone. A tour with Camino Pampa will add incomparable depth to any trip to Buenos Aires!

An interesting day on the pampa. We were looking for a tour that would provide us with some knowledge of the history, geography, and culture of the Buenos Aires province, so we could connect our understanding of the economy and culture of the environs with the city of Buenos Aires. This was the perfect tour to take. Juan Manuel was the most amazing, knowledgeable, and accessible guide. The town of San Antonio de Areco is an historical town, on the Camino Real, settled by Jesuits and gauchos. The gaucho culture really comes alive here, and the exquisite crafts of silversmithing and leather work are fantastic to witness. This craftwork is explained to show the deeply personal and historical connections created here. After a great tour of the town center, we moved on to the estancia, El Ombu de Areco. The lunch there - asado and fantastic salads - was one of the very best meals we had in our week in Buenos Aires. Horseback riding for about 45 minutes allowed us to gain a perspective of the working ranch and an up-close view of the fields and birds that are unique to the area. We were treated to singing by Oscar. His musical poetry was beautifully translated by Juan Manuel and that helped us to learn so much more about the gaucho and rural culture. Everyone associated with the ranch, from the owner to the staff, were friendly and welcoming and we really learned so much from them. We were able to get access to the history and culture of Argentina and Buenos Aires in this wonderful day trip and we so appreciate the generous efforts of these local owners and guides to share their crafts and talents.

Amazing trip. If you're looking for a great tour and a day out of BA, do this one. We had an amazing time. They picked the four of us up at our house and took us by van to San Antonio de Areco. We got to spend time in the town and checking out the shops. Make sure you stop for chocolates. Then we went over to the estancia for empanadas and wine followed by a 30-40 minute horse ride. Lunch afterwards was amazing. So much food and it was tasty. We absolutely loved this trip. My mother just kept saying in awe that she never thought she'd be riding horses in Argentina.

A truly wonderful experience. We do not normally take tours, usually being independent travellers but in this case we made an exception and how happy we were. We met Juan Manuel in the main square of St Antonio de Areco and right from the off he was fantastic. Passionate, enthusiastic, genuinely knowledgable about so many subjects and a charming and likeable individual to boot. We stood on a street corner chatting and were amazed how many locals stopped to say hello, we were made to feel part of the community. We visited the leather workshop and also the silversmith. The leather work was beautiful but the silver work was just truly stunning. In both cases we met the proprietor and spent at least 30 min chatting to them. This was all because of Juan Manuel and his contacts.We then moved on to the Estansia and had an excellent lunch, including wine or beer, served by the gauchos. This was all outside in the paddock and was followed by some Gaucho music from Oscar - a real character. We also enjoyed the horse whisperer, of course this is a tourist attraction but it is wonderful to see the bond between the Gaucho and his horse. We also came to appreciate the culture and values of these marvellous men - really heart warming. All this was followed by our first ever horse ride, a perfect end to a perfect day. If you do nothing else whilst in Buenos Aires take this tour and give Juan Manuel our regards, he is a true force of nature!

Do NOT miss this!. One of the highlights of our 4 day stay in Buenos Aires was this tour of San Antonio de Areco and the Estancia. I found this trip only a couple of days before our departure for Argentina and I'm so glad that I did. Miguel picked us up promptly from our hotel and was our driver during the visit. He spoke little English but made lots of attempts to point out various sites on interest on the way. The guide, Manuel, was outstanding and easily the best guide we have ever had anywhere in the world. What he doesn't know about the town, gaucho life, and Argentina in general is not worth knowing. He is the sort of person you can just sit and chat to for hours and indeed we did! We are still raving about the trip to anyone who will listen!

Overall a good trip. We were picked up at hotel on time by Miguel and driven through constant rain to the town of Areco where we were met by our guide Laura. There was insufficient time to see all the town has to offer but she was highly knowledgeable about the history and various Artisans and we were welcomed by many locals. After a short drive we were met by another 4 wheel drive truck to take us there and we drove over muddy and slippery surfaces. Upon arrival Manueline greeted us and offered drinks by the fire and we talked about the property and the people. We then went on a carriage ride through swarms of Mosquitos which was not pleasant and this lasted about 20 minutes.An excellent lunch and drinks were served and then Oscar the elder gaucho played guitar. Following which we returned back to the city.The promised horse riding demo and also gaucho skills were not offered nor mentioned and we were rather disappointed.Overall a good day out.

San Antonio de Areco/Estancia Tour. Everything about this tour was excellent. The arrangements were all very efficient. The driver arrived on time, and was really friendly, speaking excellent English, and chatting to us about all sorts of aspects of life in Argentina. The tour guide (Manuel) was brilliant, really friendly and very entertaining. He gave us a very interesting tour of San Antonio de Areco, with stories about the history of the place mixed in with funny stories about his childhood, and what it was like to grow up in that area. We then went off to the estancia (via an entertaining 4-wheel drive, as there had been heavy rain!), where there was an optional horse-ride followed by a fantastic asado lunch. The meat was wonderful, and the supply was never-ending. Lots of nice wine too! I would definitely recommend this tour.

Authentic, Relaxing Tour of Gaucho Culture Not To Be Missed!. My boyfriend and I enjoyed a beautiful day in the pampas thanks to our amazing, charismatic guide, Juan Manuel and the staff and gauchos at the estancia who graciously took great care of us the whole day. The love and respect Juan has for the people and traditions of Areco town really shows through as he took us around to chat with locals and to check out artisan shops and gaucho bars all while keeping us entertained with funny and engaging stories.We then made our way to a gorgeous estancia where the highlight was without a doubt the horseback riding along the sprawling estate grounds. As it was only my 2nd time on a horse, I was a bit nervous but quickly settled into the ride as my horse was calm and steady (as were all the other horses). We even had adorable border collies escorting us along the way to make sure our horses don't stray too far from the path. The ride felt like the perfect amount of time as it wasn't rushed and you really get to enjoy the fresh air and open sky. We ended the day with a delicious, endless asado all while being entertained by the beautiful music of a gaucho and his guitar and an unforgettable "horse whisperer" demonstration where a gaucho skillfully and hypnotically tames his horse. Time just flew in such a charming and relaxing atmosphere. Absolutely the best way to spend a relaxing, enjoyable day in the pampas!Special thanks to our driver, Cesar, who went out of his way to take us to a tasty spot to enjoy some delicious regional "jamon crudo". A tour that should not be missed!!

Surprisingly great!. This excursion was a nice break from the city of Buenos Aires. The estancia was beautiful, peaceful and relaxing and our tour guide, Juan Manuel, was enthusiastic, engaging, and knowledgeable. We particularly enjoyed the food and the horses! Awesome experience!

Authentic. A truly authentic trip into the gauchos culture and history...with a very knowledgeable tour guide.
100% recommended!!

A true Argentinean country experience. Juan Manuel was our tour guide and he was so informative, social and lively. We loved him and loved how he was able to make is feel extremely welcomed in San Antonio de Areco and the estancia. This tour is a breath of fresh air from the city of Buenos Aires. We especially enjoyed the horse ride and the country estate lunch. The food was amazing, as well as, the people. You'll really get a wholesome country experience on this tour.

A truly memorable day at Ombu estancia and San Antonio de Areco!. Many thanks to Juan Manuel and Guillermo for such a well planned day. The execution was flawless. We so appreciate how you established the groups with hosts to really create a most personalized experience. Juan Manuel is in his element and shares his love and respect for San Antonio de Areco, the Ombu Estancia including its owners, staff and gauchos. Food was wonderful, the setting was idyllic and this has definitely been a highlight for us after spending some 51 days in South America! Great photo ops everywhere! Juan Manuel is really amazing. He is so engaging and well versed in the history, culture of the place and full of personal experiences to give it life. My husband and I had a a terrific time and "merci beaucoup" Juan Manuel pour les conversations en francais! J'espere que tu iras a Montreal et a Quebec un de ces jours! Le sirop d'erable est fantastic! All the best to you and continue to do what you do so well!

A great day. We just took the tour with Gillermo yesterday. It was a wonderful day. He filled us with fascinating facts about Argentine history as we toured the lovely town of San Antonio de Areco. Then we went to the Estancia, a beautiful setting, for the best empanadas we have ever had. Then horseback riding around the pampas (they had special horses for us newbies and they were very tame). The lunch was perfect as was the entertainment. Our hosts at the Extancia could not have been more wecoming. We higly recommend this day trip. Well worth it!

Fabulous place and people. Juan Manuel is great!. The whole experience was a delight from the beginning to the end. Everything was arranged at perfection.In the morning, we were cordially picked up at our hotel by Andres and had a very pleasant drive. When we arrived in San Antonio de Areco, we were greeted by our guide: Juan Manuel, ("one man well". ) who is outstanding. He took us around the lovely historical town of San Antonio, and provided us with enriching information and many details about Argentinian culture. Juan Manuel speaks fluent English and French like a native speaker. His erudition and passion about culture, history and people around the world made our visit deeply interesting and meaningful. Besides, he was also very kind and attentive to everyone. We then drove to the charming Estancia and enjoyed every moment of the day. Guillermo (the organizer and owner) warmly welcomed us at our arrival and we were offered yummy empenadas with a glace of wine, before a nice horseback riding in the pampas. At our return, a delicious and copious lunch (a variety of parillada, salads, desert) was served in the shade of the majestic ombu tree, accompanied by Oscar, an old gaucho-payador, performing on his guitar. Finally, the horse whispering demonstration was amazing.Time flew by like a charm in this relaxed and friendly atmosphere. We were sad to leave! I also want to point out the fact, that after Andre dropped us back, I realized that I forgot my jacket in the van, and Andres made all the way back at our hotel to return it.Not to be missed if you are in Buenos Aires!

A very enjoyable day..... A nice change up from Buenos Aires...well worth the time!Guillermo puts together a very memorable experience.We were amazed how this magical little town manages to hold on to their traditions. The tour of the town gives you great insight into the local culture. The working estancia is positioned in a very beautiful setting...surrounded by many exotic trees. The gaucho show was terrific!

Everything we hoped for, and more.. We realized that there were a number of 'touristy' gaucho shows, and while I recognize that this was a show for tourists, it just seemed authentic. We loved it.Guillermo is a down-to-earth person, who loves his town (San Antonio de Areco) and keeping his heritage intact. He has successfully done that. Guillermo has found a fantastic estancia to tie his business to. Everything is done in a classy way.The gauchos are 'real'. (who couldn't love Oscar??) The estancia is 'real'. The 'horse whisperer' display is mind boggling.Thank you Guillermo for the absolutely fantastic day! We loved BsAs, however we wouldn't have missed this daytrip out of town for anything!Well done! Great value!

A day with Camino Pampa. A professional service, far from usual commercial offers, coupled with friendly and hearty atmosphere. In San Antonio de Areco you greet the people smiling, the Draghi family warmly welcomes you and at the Estancia el Ombù the gauchos and personnel take care of you in a great way, spending time to explain how to saddle a horse or prepare a home-made chimichurri.The place and the food are at the top,the final gaucho and horse demonstration is a unique souvenir to bring at home. Congratulations to Guillermo and Juan Manuel: be proud of your life in San Antonio.

A breath of fresh air!. What a special day! We were on the last day of a cruise and took this tour with 6 others from the ship. This was our only day in Buenos Aires, so to take this tour meant that we did not get to see the city at all - a big decision, but the right decision! This whole day was one of the most relaxing experiences we have ever had. San Antonio de Areco is a lovely little town and it was great to be able to wander round with a small group and not be surrounded by crowds. The estancia was a delight - we opted for the carriage ride, while others did the horseback ride. Lunch under the shade of the trees, local wines, songs from a gaucho and finally the most beautiful 'horse whisperer' demonstration that brought tears to our eyes. The interaction between the gaucho and his horse was the loveliest demonstration of absolute trust between man and horse. An altogether special day - don't miss it.

The best day out!!. Me and my boyfriend recently experienced a day out of the city with Caminos Pampas tour. I honestly can not recommend it enough. We are living in Buenos Aires atm and it was so fantastic to get out of the city into the country side and to visit the beautiful little town, San Antonio. Guillermo arranged our pick up for us right outside our house In a really comfy mini van. Once we arrived to San Antonio we were greated by our guide Juan Manuel. Such a friendly guy and really great guide. He looked after us for the day. We spent a little time in the town exploring the area and being taught about the history. Then, Manuel took us to the BEST chocolate shop ever. A tiny little place where all the chocolate is made in the shop, if you love chocolate this is a must! You then head over to the estancia, the grounds are breathtakingly beautiful. You get to ride a horse which is great fun, then there is a fantastic parrillada with so much food being served. It's such a relaxing experience and a great day out of the city.

Even the weather cooperated!. We discovered the full-day Gaucho experience at San Antonio Estancia on TripAdvisor.Guillermo made all of the arrangements for us in Buenos Aires. However, he was unable to control the weather...at least early on!We completed a cruise on Silversea Silver Spirit and arranged a private tour for the day and then delivery to the airport for our international flight. The logistics were made easy by Guillermo.The morning we disembarked was like a monsoon! The rain was extraordinary and flooding in Buenos Aires was everywhere making travel hazardous. We considered cancelling since we knew there was a long drive to the ranch. But, we decided to make the best of it.We were met at the port by Miguel. The bad weather delayed his arrival and he was quite apologetic about that. The bigger problem was how to get our baggage in his car. All was done and we were on our way. The rain seemed to get heavier and we wondered if we were going to be able to enjoy our tour.At San Antonio de Areco we were met by Manuel. He had umbrellas and a good positive outlook. We did a brief walking tour of San Antonio and learned quite a bit about the gaucho and its importance to Argentina. Manuel was very knowledgeable and very entertaining.We were met again by Miguel who drove us out of San Antonio to a working ranch out in the country. I had just commented to Debra about all the muddy roads off the highway and wondered how anyone could possibly travel on one given the heavy rain. Well, we were about to find out! Miguel met a four-drive vehicle where we reconnected with Manuel for a several mile drive on that seemingly impassable road. I will say the ride was exciting. Antonio was the driver as well as the foreman of the ranch. His driving was quite good in the hazardous mud. Manuel joked about the scary ride but I told him I had done that before only I had a beer in my hand at the time. Everyone laughed and relaxed.We got to the ranch and enjoyed a drink and snack on a covered patio. Then, all of a sudden, the sun came out and every cloud quickly disappeared. We soon went out on a trail ride with two gauchos and four dogs. This was not a routine tourist ride. It was the real thing! The dogs kept flushing birds out of the brush. After about an hour of riding, we returned to the ranch house for lunch and entertainment. The food was plentiful and delicious. The oldest gaucho sang to us while Manuel translated. We met the family and saw how they worked together on the ranch. Very enjoyable. But, the best was yet to come.After lunch Manuel asked if we would like to see a demonstration of a horse whisperer. We saw a young gaucho put a horse through a number of moves without anything but a bridle. The horse acted more like a big dog doing tricks for his master. Imagine a large horse on his back with his four hooves in the air while the gaucho was laying or standing on top of him! Then, Debra was invited to join them!Debra and the horse laid on the ground together for several minutes. She used the horse as a pillow and the horse never moved! Everyone was quite impressed at her courage.We videotaped the ride back so that everyone could see us in a four-wheel drive in a mud race!Manuel and all were just terrific. They were concerned that we did not enjoy ourselves because of the weather. We enjoyed ourselves immensely!This is a unique experience and I recommend it to all, regardless of age!

A Tour not to be missed. We took this tour and enjoyed San Antonio de Arecho and the ranch. Very personal. The guide lives in the town and knows everyone. The ranch was exceptional.Overall, a wonderful way to get a feel for the country.

Worth every penny.... We spent a while contemplating a trip to a ranch and we were worried about spending a day in a tourist trap, watch locals fake things and feeling generally sold to. Not with this, amazing tour! Right from the first smile from Hose Maria, our excellent driver, you knew that this tour would be different. So to summarise, this trip does not feel touristy, the driver and guide Manwell, have superb knowledge of their town, culture and country and are very positive and engaging. It's incredible to think that they do this almost every day and still seem as enthusiastic each time!The town is beautiful and you are not made to feel out of place - Manwell, the guide, is a local hero here and if anything it's a good feeling to be walking with him!The ranch and the gauchos will blow your mind. I sat there in wonder, sipping fine Malbec, eating BBQ steak listening to a 70 year old gaucho sing a song with his guitar whilst, I'm not joking here, Hawks flew above us. The environment feels authentic, the team are welcoming and the whole day was just superb!Worth the money? Money can't easily buy an experience like this one!

Great day. Unsure about pricing. We agree with everyone that this is a very memorable day. Our guide Juan Miguel was one of the more impressive people we've met in our travels (or anywhere), with just an extraordinarily knowledge of the Pampas, Argentina, and the world. We loved the horseback riding and the food. And the place is quite beautiful.We were quoted $170pp online, and then asked for a price cut and got to $150pp. One other couple we asked had gotten $150 from the getgo. Wonder what other stories there were.There seemed to be lots of people in the same place, with the same everything we had except for our (outstanding) guide. They may well have paid significantly less.

Great day out in the real Argentine Pampas.. We highly recommend this tour as a contrast to the city of Buenos Aires.We were picked up by our driver right on time at our doorstep in his impeccable car.Our guide Juan Manuel really worked hard to make sure we had a memorable day, and he certainly succeeded. The weather was very wet on our day, but we still managed to fit in horse riding and a great asado meal. The 4x4 drive down the mud track was an adventure in itself! A wonderful day out in the country!

A day in Areco. This is a way to experience again life in a small town, where our common humanity seems to flows so easily, whether one is in Argentina or our home in Canada and the USA.Our tour guide, Juan Manuel Hernandez, was a font of staccato information, all of it interesting and relevant. His energy level borders on that of a ferret after his third cup of expresso, and he knows everyone in town, and the area. He easily got us access to the most interesting people, both in town and on the estancia. We enjoyed every facet of the trip, even the military type truck ride to the estancia over the barely-passable washed out dirt road. By the time we left for the day, we felt like we had spent a wonderful day with our cousin in the country. Guillermo is the tour owner and his quiet presence in the background makes it all work like a charm.

Camino Pampa: Tour San Antonio de Areco & Estancia. What a wonderful experience - one I will never forget! Laura was the most amazing guide, so knowledgeable and great fun. Lunch at the Estancia was delicious. The highlight for me was the wonderful gauchos - young and old! The display of horse whispering skills was mesmerising.Just don't forget to take plenty of mosquito spray!!!

Don't miss this slice of Argentina. The two of us were picked up at our hotel for this private tour. We arrived in the colonial town of San Antonia de Areco and were given a very personal tour by a charming native, Guillermo. He had such pride in his town and knew wonderful details of old and new aspects of the town. From here he took us to the estancia where we were greeted with delicious empanadas and then enjoyed a carriage ride through the property. It was helpful that we spoke Spanish because we could talk to the driver about his life on the ranch. The meal was excellent, as well. All in all, I would definitely recommend this day trip out of the city to see another aspect of Argentina.

Overall a show for the tourists. The guide was good and interesting. The meal was correct. But, we were expecting a real life on a farm,with gauchos keeping a herd of cows, and the true work of the so gauchos was to amuse the visitors. The farm is not really operating as an estancia with real gauchos. It is operating only as a tourist place.

Great day combining history and fun. Really enjoyed this authentic tour. We expected a type if small theme park but instead we got the real thing. Picked up at hotel by English speaking driver who drive us to historical town. Met by locally born guide William who was very knowledgeable and charming with excellent English who gave us great tour then took us on to working estancia (ranch) where we rode horses with the gauchos and had excellent lunch. Well worth the cost. Estancia also a B & B.

Excellent Day Trip. Two of us took the Areco Town and Estancia tour from the cruise terminal and were joined by another four people, who were going on a cruise the next day. It was raining heavily on this day but it cleared up later in the day when we got to the Estancia. The first part of the tour included visiting San Antonia de Areco which is a lovely historical town. We were joined by Guillermo in Areco who showed us a pub, studio of a gaucho artist and a silversmith workshop. After this visit we went to estancia. It had rained so much that we had to be driven by 4 X 4's to get there. At the estancia we were greeted by the hostress who gave us a choice of drinks (beer, wine, pop or water) along with empanadas. The estancia is a beautifully groomed, well maintained 900 acre traditional farm where can stay overnight if you wish. After the snack we opted to go for the carriage ride before lunch. The lunch was served in a charmingly decorated building with fresh linens and flowers. The lunch consisted of all you could eat salads, sausages, chicken and beef along with the choice of drinks. The desert was ice cream along with coffee. After lunch, Oscar (a gaucho) played the guitar and sang some traditional gaucho songs. This was followed by a demonstration of horse whispering. After that we were driven by the 4 X 4s back to the highway where we transferred to the van. We were then driven to the cruise terminal after we dropped off the other people. It was a very enjoyable day which allowed us to see the rural areas of Argentina. The driver, tour guides and hostess all spoke excellent English, so we got to learn all about the traditions of the gauchos. I would highly recommend this tour if you have a full day available to you while visiting Buenos Aires.

Outstanding tour. My wife and I honestly feel that this is one of the best tour experiences that we have ever had. Juan Manuel was an extremely erudite and charismatic tour guide. It is obvious that everyone in the are knows and respects him and he brings in a degree of attention and knowledge that is without equal. Even the flat tire on our 4x4 on the way in was handled with aplomb and humor. He truly was a master of ceremony at the estancia but always had our interests front and center. Anyone not availing themselves of this experience will miss one of the highlights of a visit to Buenos Aires.

Argentinian History, part 1. Take this tour and revel in your ability to see and understand a critical building block of Argentinian culture thru the eyes of a talented and helpful group of guides. Our group of 5 were picked up at our apartment in BA and deposited there at the end of a perfect day. In between we learned much about the origins of the country; with particular emphasis on the development of small towns and ranches...and the parallels to our own American history are exact. There are many 'tours' of estancias available during your stay in BA, what makes this tour standout is the personal attention of the guides, their knowledge of the country and importantly the immersive qualities of the tour that allow you to get a real sense of the country. I can't praise Camino Pampa enough...take this tour!

An excellent day trip. My fiancee and I took the Camino Pampa tour and found it a lovely experience.We were picked up from our hotel in Buenos Aires and taken to San Antonio were we met our guide Manuel. He first gave us a tour of the town, speaking of the history of the town and of gaucho culture. Manuel spoke excellent English and was on good terms with many of the locals, so we visited the local church and a number of shops to get a glimpse of the local culture.Then it was back in the car for the estancia tour. We met the owner of the estancia and began with a snack of empanadas and beer. Then there was a short horseback ride through the paddock - nothing special, but it was my first time on a horse so exciting for me nonetheless. The horses were clearly very well trained and cared for.Back at the estancia, lunch was served. As others have mentioned, it was heaven for a meat lover: it started with sausages then all the chicken, steak and ribs that you could eat. Salad was served, and to drink was a choice of wine or beer. Dessert and coffee were accompanied by a musical performance from one of the old gauchos.After lunch, one of the gauchos gave a demonstration of their horse whispering techniques - very impressive. The day finished off with a demonstration of their horse herding skills.All in all, it was a great day out. The food was amazing, the sights and cultural exposure fantastic. Manuel was clearly passionate about the region and the people and was an engaging host. (On a side note, he'd also been to Antarctica so we had some good discussions about our pending cruise to the southern continent.) Yes, it was very touristy but it didn't feel at all exploitative or excessively contrived.

Terrific area, a wonderful contrast to BA. Juan Manuel is outstanding. Terrific tour, totally different from the City of Buenos Aries. Beautiful small country town where everyone knew Juan Manuel since he grew up there. But don't be fooled, he has traveled the world and has amazing insight as well as encyclopedic knowledge of all people and history. Expert on Gaucho culture and history.Shares all with you, funny and friendly, it's like having a best friend show you the country. Stories of growing up there really help you understand the culture. The Estancia is amazing, the Gauchos and horsemanship incredible. Never was a fan of group dining but the lunch was fantastic and great fun. Not to be missed and what a great example of the differences within the country. Fantastic tour, fantastic guide, I would do it a 2nd time without hesitation. Highly recommended.

Wonderful Experience!. We searched and searched for an estancia trip that was personalized and finally found it through Camino Pampa; this was truly a wonderful experience.Our guide was the owner of Camino Pampa; Guillermo Guereno; he picked up the five of us in the morning at our rental apartment in Buenos Aires for the approximately 1:45 minute trip to San Antonio de Areco; this is Guillermo's home town; a charming city of 20,000 people (and I think Guillermo knows all of them!) We toured the old historical Gaucho taverns; the town square, the church and various artisans; we then drove to a lovely estancia that is still a working ranch; what a treat. There was horseback riding and wagon rides included as well as a wonderful bar-b-que lunch with wine. The gauchos' performed songs and there was a demonstration of horse whispering that was incredibly moving and amazing.I can't say enough about this trip; Guillermo is an kind and charming man; we learned a lot about Argentina and the culture during the drive and the visit to the town and estancia.For someone looking to get out of the city for the day; I highly recommend this trip; you are not hearded onto a big bus and lumped in with a lot of other people; this was a wonderful, personal expericence and well worth the time and money. Based on all the research we did; we felt the cost of this trip; it was all inclusive; was the best option we found.

Very interesting cultural tour. The gauchos philosophies are quite different from the Cowboys of North America. That's the reason I wanted to join the tour to learn and I was not disappointed. Our guide Juan Manuel was excellent and talked with such enthusiasm in very good English. He first gave a 2 hour tour of the town of San Antonia with many historical facts. Then we were taken to one of the oldest Gaucho ranch outside of the city. We had a half hour horse back ride around the ranch led by several Gauchos, young and old. The oldest gaucho, Oscar, could also sing with his guitar. The most interesting part of the tour was a demonstration of the relationship between rider and horse. Gauchos trained their horses in a very gentle and humane way, never 'breaking' them by force. It was a illuminating experience to watch them.The tour included a very generous lunch of different cuts of beef, completed with wine from the ranch.

Excellent - We wish we could have stayed for a week. This was an excellent trip. Highly recommended. My group (6 people) were in Buenos Aires for 2 days as part of a South American cruise. We were picked up from the cruise ship terminal and returned in time for our departure. We picked up 2 other people in BA, so our group was only 8 people and is an excellent size for this tour. Our time in Areco was a bit short, but our guide there (a teacher during the school year) was very knowledgeable and friendly. The Estancia is beautiful. There were probably about 50 guests at the estancia while we were there, and I was told that this was a busy day. It should also be noted that the Estancia is also a guest house, so you can stay there overnight if your time permits.We went for a short horseback ride, had some of the best empanadas that we had in south America, and relaxed under a 100 year old tree while enjoying the country. Then it was lunch time. Bring your appetite. If you have never had a south American Asado before, you should know that there is lots of meat, and it comes in many courses. Do note that the first course of meats (mainly sausage) is only the first course. Some people at our table were full before the Chicken, Steak (various cuts) and ribs showed up. There is no veggie option that i saw, but lots of salad, wine and beer.The horse whisperer is amazing.If you are there on a hot day, a nice swim in the pool is also very refreshing. It was an excellent way to spent a day, and our whole group (4 - 30 year olds and 2 in their 60s) really enjoyed it all.
wonderful day. Everything was nice and perfect with our guide who speaks French! So different from BA, like a small paradise.

A thoroughly relaxing and enjoyable day. We had a wonderful time. Our driver Miguel picked us up at 8:45 in Palermo Hollywood as promised in his comfortable a/c Toyota and drove us 1:45 to San Antonio de Areca, where we met our guide, Laura. Her pride in her city was very evident in her informative and enjoyable tour, and it seems as a retired ESL teacher, she knows very many people. The Estancia Ombu de Areca was beautiful, a full lunch with a variety of meats was provided, and the Gauchos were quite impressive. Guillermo, our tour organizer also greeted and inquired if we had enjoyed our tour. It was an enjoyable respite fom the hustle and bustle of B.A. November is the month to visit for the Gaucho Parade and celebration, and March April the weather is milder. This is an all day trip.

Camino Pampa: Tour San Antonio de Areco Town & Estancia A super day!. A very enjoyable day in the countryside. The town was interesting, the estancia very nice, the horseback riding fun and most of all the guides and driver were exceptional warm , friendly and informative. Overall a super day!

Had a Fantastic Time!. What a wonderful way to spend a day when visiting Buenos Aires! Juan Manuel was a wonderful and extremely knowledgable and personable guide. We spent a couple of hours touring the incredibly charming little town of San Antonio de Areco, followed by a truly delightful lunch and horseback ride at a beautiful Estancia, where we got to enjoy some excellent steaks and chorizo and mingle with the Gauchos! Highly recommend!

Juan Manuel = great guide = great tour. After four days in BA, we definitely needed to get a break from the city and spend some time in the countryside. We booked this tour following the recommendations on trip advisor and did not regret it. We visited the local town with its crafts store, the local pub and church before going to the estancia. The explanations of Manuel really brought the stories and the history of the gauchos and San Antonio alive. He makes people feel welcome and engages with them on a personal level no matter which country they are from. He is full of interesting and entertaining stories and makes the tour really memorable. There is a nice and relaxed atmosphere at the estancia. The short horse ride is very relaxing and easy to do even for those without horse riding experienced. The horses basically follow the main horse on their own. The small "show" of the gauchos and their horses is not what you would see in a circus. It focuses in showing how close the bond is between a gaucho and his horse and how much the animals trust the gauchos. A good tour in general, a great tour with Manuel!

Fun day of shopping and gaucho life. The company was very responsive to our requests prior to the trip. They picked us up on time and took us to the town of San Antonio de Areco, where we met Laura, a wonderful, witty, informative tour guide. After touring the town for about an hour, we were taken to an estancia where we rode horses, had a delicious barbecue lunch, heard a gaucho sing, and watched a gaucho do some horse whispering. A great day!

Excellent Gaucho tour. A trip to Buenos Aires is not complete if you do not visit an Estancia to see the gauchos. We arranged a gaucho tour with Guillermo from Camino Pampa before arriving in Buenos Aires on a cruise. Guillermo arranged for a driver to pick us up at the cruise terminal, and it took us about an hour to reach San Antonio de Areco, a very traditional town where the gauchos all over the country gather once a year. In this town, Guillermo our guide met us and walked with us through this fascinating town to share with us the exciting stories about the gauchos. After about 1 hour, we went to the Estancia El Ombu which is the only working Estancia open to tourists in that area. The Estancia is very beautiful, lush and green. We were served empanadas and cold beverages including beer on arrival. Then we had the option of riding a horse or going on a traditional carriage around the Estancia. We had an Argentinean BBQ lunch when we got back. The food was excellent, and beer and red wine was included in the lunch. When we were having our desert, we were entertained by the guitar playing of the oldest gaucho of the Estancia, who is also the grandson of the most famous gaucho of Argentina. We were also entertained by a horse whisperer who was amazing. Guillermo made sure that we were back at the cruise terminal 2 hours before the departure of our cruise.We want to thank Guillermo for giving us such an amazing day. Highly recommended!

Juan Manuel is Marvelous. If you want to tour San Antonio de Areca with someone who has the passion and sole for the Pampas, ask for Juan Manuel. We spent the day with Manuel and it was simply fantastic. For the town square, through the wonderful little shops, out to the estancia. The trip was very worthwhile, however it was the wonderful commentary of our guide that made it special. Manuel is truly a renaissance man who has had amazing adventures and engages his guests in the most special way. E:mail him at onemanwellfrance@yahoo.com and let him revel you with his stories!

The best way of getting to know Argentinean pampas. My friends and I (11 in total) spent one Sunday in October 2013 in San Antonio de Areco and Estancia El Ombú, all arranged by the excellent agency Camino Pampa. Guillermo, our host, picked up punctually at our hotel in downtown Buenos Aires and from the very first minute he started telling us fascinating stories about the origins of the Pampas and the gauchos. The trip took around an hour and it was very relaxing. First, we made a stop at San Antonio de Areco, a very traditional town. There were very nice pulperías (gaucho bars) to visit, beautiflully handicrafted souvenirs (specially in silver) and delicious icecream and pastry. After around 1 hour we departed to Estancia El Ombu. The place was very nice, green and wide. You could really feel the spirit of the Pampas here! We were greeted with a big smile by the owners, who were prompt to serve us empanadas and cool beverages. After a nice chill moment, those who wanted to ride took a tour around and those of us who do not ride took a round trip in a traditional carriage. It was fun!When we came back, it was time for lunch and we sat under the trees along a long table. The food was excellent, all the typical things you should eat in a real Argentinean parrillada: sausages (chorizos), blood sausages (morcillas), pork, red meat and, finally, the speciality: crispy and juicy grilled lamb!After the lunch we were presented with a traditional show, including a troubadour who left nobody untouched.We left the Estancia with our hearts filled with gratitude for a very special day and we felt that we'll surely be back some day! Most of all we would like to thank Gillermo who with his humble but very experienced approach made our visit one of a kind!

Exceeded expectations. The tour was exceptional. The driver picked us up promptly at the downtown hotel. He was very courteous, well informed and provided much useful information on the drive out to the Estancia.Our guide was truly one of the best we have ever experienced. He was well versed in history, science, literature and had a great sense of humor. The tour of the Town and the time on the Estancia exceeded our expectations. A day we will remember for years to come. We highly recommend Camino Pampa!!!
NOT TO BE MISSED. It's all been said. It was a fabulous day in every respect. Superbly organized, brilliantly executed and a ton of fun. Just do it.

Great Gaucho Experience!. We have traveled all around the world and taken a number of day trips. Not only was this tour a highlight during our trip to Buenos Aires, it is one of the best "tours" we have ever taken. From the moment we were picked up at our hotel until we were dropped off, it was a fantastic experience! The tour of the local town with exceptional guide was very informative and interesting. The estancia was superb and filled with unique experiences! Highly recommended!

Only way to go - Camino Pampa!. We knew when we went to Argentina that we would want to visit an Estancia. Little did we know that in the process, we'd meet one of the best tour guides in the world and have a day that was perfect in many, many ways (except for the horse flies...).I spent 3 days researching companies to take the 5 of us out of Buenos Aires to visit a ranch, and learn a bit more about the culture of this wonderful place. I found trips for all day excursions that cost between $82 and $200 per person - door to door, including horseback ride, food, and some form of entertainment from Gouchos. Although price mattered, value and quality were what we were searching for. We didn't want to have the same tour bus experience with 200 other people, nor did we want to be left to wander around for 2 or 3 hours waiting for other people to come. So the TripAdvisor reviews mattered.This was how we discovered Juan Manuel and Camino Pampa!Always a bit skeptical, I knew it would be fine when they responded to our request to book the trip quickly, told us exactly when our driver would arrive, as well as his name, and what to expect in terms of timing, and the specific tour. And they delivered.From Jose Maria's commentary as we drove our of BA in the small 8 passenger van, to meeting Juan Manuel in San Antonio de Areco, and on to the Estanzia - it all went very smoothly, we were never rushed, never bored, always engaged.The tour of the town was great - with stops in a traditional Gaucho bar, a visit to the Church, silver smith and leather shops - none overwhlemingly touristy, all high quality, where we could meet and chat with the owners/craftspeople. Because Juan Manuel is not only from San Antonio de Areco, but also because he spent half his life living in other parts of the world, he had many fascinating stories, and footnotes that helped us to learn how Argentina came to be, and also about the heritage of the people of his home town - which is one of the premier basis for Gaucho culture in South America.The visit to the Estanzia was equally superb - from the hour long horse back ride through the pastures to the multi course lunch, walks around the grounds and in the houses to the songs and horsewhispering of the gaucho's - all with maybe 30 people in total - made for a much more appealing, pleasant visit.I am very glad we chose this specific tour company and recommend them highly - you will be treated very well, from intelligent, friendly people. If you want to save a few dollars, I am told you should book directly with them, as the hotels or tourist agencies will add up to $50 on top of the fees the Camino Pampa charge.Cheers.

What is Argentina without gauchos?. This visit to the town and gaucho ranch was the perfect ending to an exciting 3-week tour in Easter Island, Patagonia, and other places in Chile and Argentina. It always seems a bit "risky" booking a tour online in a foreign country, but I can attest to the truly excellent service provided by Guillermo and his associates. They were punctual, hospitable, informative, and professional in every way. My friends and I completely enjoyed the peacefulness and natural surroundings of the estancia, and we will never forget the amazing horsemanship demonstration by the gaucho. If you are going to Argentina, how can you resist the opportunity to visit a gaucho ranch?

An unforgettable experience you don't want to miss out on.. I've been studying in Buenos Aires for the past 5 months and my day in San Antonio de Areco was definitely one of my favorites so far. Our tour guide was incredible and it was a day I won't soon forget!!

Excellent tour along with a terrific asado. I highly recommend this tour. I am from Argentina and was there this past november with my daughter and husband to visit my family. I had been told about a wonderful gaucho festival which occurs in November in the town of San Antonio de Areco. Since we would be without a car in Buenos Aires, and I thought it would be nice to tack on a visit to an estancia for my daughter to see farm animals, I booked the tour. We also took along my cousin and her husband and two children (6 and 9) who are from Buenos Aires. Absolutely everyone enjoyed themselves tremendously. Unfortunately the gaucho festival was postponed due to a storm, but we had so much fun that in the end the original purpose of the trip didn't matter. San Antonio de Areco is a beautiful colonial town that has preserved its character and architecture is wonderful condition.
